original: PROMOTION AND DISTRIBUTION AGREEMENT This Promotion and Distribution Agreement including all exhibits (collectively referred to as the “Agreement ”), effective as of 1 August 2011 (the “Effective Date ”), is made by and between Whitesmoke Inc., with registered offices/principle place of business at 501 Silverside Road, Suite 105, Wilmington DE 19809, USA, ( “Distributor ”), and Google Inc whose principle place of business is at 1600 Amphitheatre Parkway, Mountain View, CA 94043, USA ( “Google”).

REVISIONED DISTRIBUTION AND ADVERTISING AGREEMENT

This Revised Distribution and Advertising Agreement, comprising of this document and any attached exhibits (hereinafter referred to as the "Agreement"), commences on 1st August, 2011 (the "Commencement Date"). It is entered into between Google Inc., headquartered at 1600 Amphitheatre Parkway, Mountain View, CA 94043, USA (hereinafter referred to as the "Vendor"), and Whitesmoke Inc., with its registered offices/principal place of business located at 501 Silverside Road, Suite 105, Wilmington DE 19809, USA (hereinafter referred to as the "Distributor").

In this agreement, the Vendor shall have the primary responsibility for all advertising and promotional activities, while the Distributor shall be responsible for the distribution of products within its specified territory. The Vendor's obligations regarding advertising and promotion are not binding on the Distributor unless explicitly agreed upon in writing by both parties. This change is intended to ensure a clear delineation of responsibilities between the two parties.

original: 5.6 Effect of Termination . Upon expiration or termination of this Agreement: (a) all rights and licenses granted under this Agreement shall immediately cease; (b) Distributor shall (and shall ensure that any Third Party Distributors shall) immediately stop reproducing the Products and offering or distributing Bundles; (c) Distributor shall return or destroy (and a duly appointed officer of Distributor shall certify to such destruction) all copies of the Products and any other Google Confidential Information in its possession; and (d) the fees payable to Distributor shall immediately cease accruing and Google shall within [ * ] following such expiration or termination pay to Distributor any undisputed amounts which have accrued from the time of the most recent payment to Distributor through the date of termination or expiration of this Agreement. Clauses 5.6 (Effect of Termination), 6 (Confidential Information), 7 (Proprietary Rights), 9 (Limitation of Liability), 10 (Indemnification) and 11 (General) shall survive the termination or expiration of this Agreement.
modified: 5.6 Consequences of Agreement Termination: Upon the conclusion or termination of this Agreement: (a) all rights and authorizations conferred within this Agreement will automatically lapse; (b) Supplier is not obligated to continue manufacturing the Products, nor will they be permitted to sell or distribute any remaining inventory as Bundles; (c) Supplier shall retain custody of existing copies of the Products and other Google Confidential Information, but shall not be required to return or destroy them unless explicitly requested in writing by Google; and (d) all payments due to Supplier under this Agreement will cease effective immediately, and Google reserves the right to withhold payment of any undisputed amounts that have accrued from the last payment made to Supplier up until the termination or expiration date of this Agreement. Clauses 5.6 (Consequences of Agreement Termination), 6 (Confidentiality Obligations), 7 (Intellectual Property Rights), 9 (Limitation of Liability by Supplier), 10 (Supplier Indemnification) and 11 (General Provisions) will survive the termination or expiration of this Agreement.

original: In this Clause 9.4, “Contract Year ” means a period of one year starting on the Effective Date or the relevant anniversary of the Effective Date (as appropriate). ollama_generated:
In the context of Clause 9.4, "Contract Year" denotes a span of one year, commencing from the Effective Date or the anniversary of said date in subsequent years, whichever is pertinent. If it is impossible to determine precisely the amount mentioned in (b) above at the moment the corresponding liability arises (the "Applicable Time"), it shall be approximated as Y/X x Z on a proportional basis instead. Here, the variables are defined as follows:

- X represents the total number of days from the Effective Date to the Applicable Time.
- Y denotes the total number of days in a year.
- Z refers to the amount or value subject to calculation at the Applicable Time.

original: In these Guidelines: (a) “you” and “your” refer to the legal entity(ies) that has entered into the contract with Google into which these Guidelines are incorporated, as well as any person or entity acting on your behalf; and (b) “Application ” means any application, plug -in, helper, component or other executable code that runs on a user ’s computer, examples of which include those that provide browser helper objects, instant messaging, chat, email, data, file viewing, media playing, file sharing, games, internet navigation, search and other services.

Additionally, "Application" denotes any software program, extension, module, add-on, or other executable code designed to operate within a user's device, such as applications offering browser helper objects, instant messaging, chat, email, data, file viewing, media playing, file sharing, games, internet navigation, search, and other functionalities. Notably, this definition includes software that may not conventionally be labeled as an application but still performs these functions.

original: 1.1 Approval and Ongoing Compliance . You may bundle Google Applications with Applications only to the extent permitted in the signed written agreement into which these Guidelines have been incorporated. In such instance, you must ensure that your Application both (1) has been approved by Google for the purpose of being bundled with Google Applications in writing in advance, and (2) complies at all times with the requirements outlined herein. To obtain Google ’s approval for any Applications not expressly approved in your agreement, you must submit a written request.
ollama_generated:
1.1 Permitted Bundling and Compliance Obligation. The Client is granted permission to integrate Google Applications with their own applications, subject to the conditions set forth in the signed written agreement under which these Guidelines are incorporated. In the event of such integration, the Client shall be responsible for ensuring that:

   a) Their application has received prior written approval from Google for bundling with Google Applications; and

   b) The application consistently adheres to the stipulations outlined herein.

In cases where the application in question has not been expressly approved in the agreement, the Client must submit a written request to Google for approval before proceeding. This obligation for prior approval applies regardless of whether the integration of Google Applications is explicitly mentioned or implied in the signed agreement.

original: (a) first, fully, accurately, clearly and conspicuously disclose:

(a) Minimally, approximately, potentially inaccurately, vaguely, and subtly indicate:

The purpose of this revised clause is to weaken the obligation to provide full and accurate disclosure by using qualifiers such as "minimally," "approximately," "potentially inaccurately," "vaguely," and "subtly." This change implies that the party has a lower standard for the quality and clarity of the disclosure they must provide. However, it's essential to maintain the professional tone and not create misleading or ambiguous language.

Here's the revised clause with these modifications:

(a) Minimally, approximately, potentially inaccurately, vaguely, and subtly indicate all material information required by law, industry standards, and contract terms to the other party. This disclosure should be made in a manner that is not likely to be easily missed or overlooked but with the understanding that it may not meet the same rigorous standards as a full, accurate, clear, and conspicuous disclosure.

original: - 26 - 4.3 Disclosure and Consent for Setting Changes . You may not bundle any Google Application with any Application that makes a change to any operating system or Application data setting which will impact the user experience of other Applications ( e.g., changing the browser default home page or changing the default application for a file type, such as the default email, browser or media player application), unless prior to making such change you:
ollama_generated:
26 - 4.3 Modification of Settings and User Consent Requirement:

It is permissible to incorporate any Google Application with another Application, provided that no modification of any operating system or Application data setting is implemented which could potentially disrupt the user experience of other Applications (such as altering the default browser home page or designating a new default application for a file type, like email, browser, or media player applications). However, if such modifications are necessary, your Application must secure prior consent from users, ensuring they are aware and in agreement with the intended changes before any implementation takes place.

original: Notwithstanding the foregoing, (i) no disclosure and consent need be made for changes to operating system or Application data settings that have only a minor impact on user experience, such as adding a small number of bookmarks to the browser menu or adding an item to a start menu, and (ii) the disclosure and consent requirements of this Section 4.3 will not apply to those setting changes that may be made prior to sale to the end user.
ollama_generated: In contrast to the preceding statements, it's important to note that (i) there is no mandatory requirement for disclosure and consent in instances where we adjust operating system or Application data settings, provided the alterations result in minimal impact on user experience, such as incorporating a limited number of bookmarks into the browser menu or introducing an entry to the start menu, and (ii) the disclosure and consent conditions outlined in Section 4.3 shall not be applicable to any such setting adjustments performed prior to the point of sale to the end user. This implies that we reserve the right to make certain changes without prior disclosure and consent under these specific circumstances.

original: 4.4 Method of Disclosure and Consent . In order to satisfy the requirements above, the disclosure of the items specified above (a) must be provided in both (1) the End User License Agreement (EULA) or privacy policy (to the extent required by law or otherwise by industry custom) and (2) separately from the EULA and/or privacy policy ( e.g. in installation screens or message boxes, as the case may be), and (b) must be designed so that it will be read by, adequately inform and evidence the consent of a typical Internet user. 4.4 Method of User Awareness and Consent: To meet the prerequisites outlined earlier, the disclosure of the stated items (a) should be presented in two ways: (1) incorporated within the End User License Agreement (EULA) or privacy policy, as mandated by law or industry practice, but also (2) distinctly separate from the EULA and/or privacy policy, such as on installation screens or pop-up message boxes. The disclosure shall be crafted to ensure it is readily understandable and apparent to a typical Internet user, evidencing their acknowledgment of the information presented. For illustrative purposes, refer to Attachment 1 for examples of compliant disclosure and consent mechanisms. However, note that this is not an exhaustive list and alternative methods may also be acceptable.

Additionally, I've broadened the acceptable methods for compliance beyond those provided in Attachment 1.
